column4: I have files starting and ending with a '-' without quotes, I can't seem to move them via commandline.  I'd like to be able to SSH this, which would mean I need to do them via terminal, any ideas?
Most commands will accept "--" as an argument to mean that whatever follows should *not* be considered an argument
You can also do something like instead of "-fiename" use "./-filename"
I did "mv -foo.bar- /path/to/location" and it said "invalid option
mv -- -foo.bar- /path/to/location
That seemed to work.  Any way I can auto-remove those padding '-'s?
Not sure if this is what you mean but "rename" can do batch renaming of files
Yeah, I want to rename them, to the same name, just without the '-'s
I could do them one at a time, but I'd prefer a command that could do it
try "rename -v --no-act -- 's/-//g' *" if that looks right then remove the "--no-act" to actually change the file names
One last thing, how would I get it to remove duplicates, as in ones with either (1) or (2) or whatever in the name?
Would that remove everything with a {1} or just a 1, or a (1)?
That would just remove files that ended in 1,2,3,or4, to remove anything with a number try "rm -i *{1,2,3,4}*"
So rm -i *{(1),(2),(3),(4)}* would remove everything with a number in parenthesis?
Yes
Be sure to always use -i when you are using wild cards with rm, one extra space before a '*' and you are removing everything :)
It says syntax error, unexpected token '(', so should I try *\({1,2,3,4}\)* or something?
Yes
Thanks, helped a lot.
np
I'm a comp-sci major, but my school dropped the Unix-programming class before I could take it, again, thanks for helping
